greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Sum of 5th powers of odd divisors of n.
reference: T. M. Apostol, Modular Functions and Dirichlet Series in Number Theory, Springer-Verlag, 1990, page 25, Exercise 15 (corrected).
link: Seiichi Manyama, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
J. W. L. Glaisher, On the representations of a number as the sum of two, four, six, eight, ten, and twelve squares, Quart. J. Math. 38 (1907), 1-62 (see p. 4 and p. 8).
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Odd Divisor Function.
Index entries for sequences mentioned by Glaisher
formula: The preceding g.f. is also 34*sigma_5(x^2) - 64*sigma_5(x^4) - sigma_5(-x), with sigma_5 the g.f. of A001160. Compare this with the Apostol reference which gives the g.f. of a(n)*(-1)^(n+1). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jan 31 2017
Multiplicative with a(2^e) = 1 and a(p^e) = (p^(5*e+5)-1)/(p^5-1) for p > 2. - _Amiram Eldar_, Sep 14 2020
Sum_{k=1..n} a(k) ~ Pi^6 * n^6 / 11340. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Sep 24 2020
mathematica: a[n_] := Select[ Divisors[n], OddQ]^5 // Total; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 34}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 25 2012 *)
f[2, e_] := 1; f[p_, e_] := (p^(5*e + 5) - 1)/(p^5 - 1); a[1] = 1; a[n_] := Times @@ f @@@ FactorInteger[n]; Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Sep 14 2020 *)
results.author: _Eric W. Weisstein_
